campaign.story:
Our intrepid author Paige Turner is back!  In Paperback Adventures, you get to play as the protagonist in one of Paige's wild brainstorming sessions. Conquer a menagerie of pulp novel characters in this solo deckbuilding word game.
Just like in the original game Paperback—and its follow up, Hardback—you will build your own deck of cards throughout the game, and those cards will have letters to help you spell words every turn. But in Paperback Adventures, instead of testing your wordsmithing wit against other players, you will use your words to defeat a series of AI enemies in "roguelike" fashion.
Paperback Adventures is a solo-focused game. It was designed from the ground up as a strategic, highly-replayable solo word game. There are also additional gameplay variants for cooperative play between two players.
Here are the stretch goals we've unlocked!
Community Stretch Goals
Part of what makes Kickstarter great is the opportunity to hear what matters most to backers. Here are some of the additions and changes we’ve made thanks to our backers’ feedback.
As the game developed and grew, we wanted every character to have their own cards and unique styles of play, but with the Fowers Games history of small box games we also wanted to keep an affordable price point for the game. So we decided on a modular system that lets you play the game whether you buy one character or several.
Here's what the Paperback Adventures core box contains:
Rulebook
Enemy Tray with Tokens (designed by Game Trayz™)
12 Enemy Cards
12 Reward Cards
7 Penalty Cards
7 Enemy Vowel and "?" Cards
26 Item Cards
26 McGuffin Cards
7 Penalty Card Sleeves
As long as you have at least one character box, the core box contains everything else you need to play the game. The core box also has space to store the bonus content from each of your character boxes (note: not all content from those boxes), allowing you to set up a new game more quickly.
So what comes in a character box? Each protagonist in Paperback Adventures plays distinctly, with different core items, starting items, and a unique 10-card starting deck. Additionally, every protagonist has their own growth deck of 50 cards that offers different paths and playstyles every game session.
But a character box doesn't only provide new content when you choose that character. Inside each character box you'll also find a few new enemies and a few new bonus items and McGuffins that go into your core box and add additional content no matter which character you pick for a given game.
Each character box has bonus enemies, items, and double-sided McGuffins (like this one!)
The more character boxes you add, the more variety and wacky combinations you get. 
Here's what comes in each character box:
Character Tray with Tokens (designed by Game Trayz™)
Character Card
6 Enemy Cards
6 Reward Cards
60 Letter Cards
6 Core Item Cards
4 Bonus Item Cards
4 Bonus McGuffin Cards
60 Letter Card Sleeves
The protagonists are not only unique from a gameplay standpoint, they also come from wildly different genres and have their own graphical style and artistic design. Here are the playable characters in Paperback Adventures:
Our final character is a Pirate—he is currently awaiting a proper name to be voted on by the backers!
Word-heavy playstyle
Barrage cards get bonuses for longer words
Can drain the enemy's life!
Can copy the effect of an item—effectively using it twice
Crew cards come back from the fatigue pile
Try out the Tabletop Simulator demo on Steam!
In a single game of Paperback Adventures, your protagonist will face off against nine randomized enemies of escalating difficulty.  To make matters worse, your health total persists from enemy to enemy. Luckily for you, each enemy also offers randomized rewards to help you power up quickly to meet the challenge. 
You'll need to beat each enemy one by one by spelling words with the cards in your hand. Each card has symbols that either damage the enemy, block the enemy's incoming damage to you, or provide you with mana so you can use your items. You'll also be able to activate the unique ability of one of your cards.
The game is divided in a trilogy structure, where you'll battle two normal enemies and a boss for each "book" in the trilogy. You can stop a game session after completing one book (~45 min) or even after any enemy through a "save game" feature that will keep your current deck, items, and rewards separate in the game's box. To beat the game, you'll need to defeat all nine enemies in the trilogy.
One goal from the outset of this game's design was to find ways to streamline the typical deckbuilding roguelike experience found in digital games for tabletop play. Two essential systems deliver the gameplay variation and combos needed for the genre while keeping player upkeep at a minimum: the splay system and the hex and boon counter system.
Your word is ready—which way will you splay?
 When you spell words each turn in Paperback Adventures, you'll need to also choose which way to splay your word, so that only one edge of each card is showing except for the top card. The only card ability visible will be on the top card, and that's the ability you activate. Here's an example of how it works:
When you splay left, you count all the icons on the left edge of each card. The top card is the last letter of the word.
When you splay right you count all the icons on the right edge of each card. The top card is the first letter of the word.
The splay system forces you to make tough choices—do you want more blocks or more hits this turn? Or maybe which card is your top card matters most. To make that decision even tougher (and to keep every battle moving), the top card also gets fatigued for the rest of the battle. You'll get it back for the next enemy, though!
Hex and boon counters allow protagonists and enemies to support a wide range of playstyles without adding too many rules and overhead for players to track. Hex counters affect the character they are on negatively, while boon counters affect the character they are on positively. So these counters are always contextual--one enemy's hex counters might cause accelerating damage, while another enemy's hex counters limit your card draw.
Here is a link to the current working rulebook for Paperback Adventures
We know that some players will want a tougher challenge, especially after completing a few runs. So we’ll be including a system called Plot Twists.
Every Plot Twist comes with two distinct challenges, one on top and one on bottom, for the entirety of your run. Here is one condition card unlocked earlier in the campaign:
Each challenge has a difficulty number assigned to it, with “1” being the lowest difficulty. Before starting a run, you can choose an overall challenge level for your run and then mix and match challenges from the various Plot Twists until the collective difficulty numbers add up to your desired challenge level. This way, you can experience brand new challenge combinations while also making the game better fit your experience and skill level.
You can splay the Plot Twists underneath your player tray, showing only the new rules from your chosen challenges so that you can quickly reference them. Those rules will stay the same throughout your run.
While Paperback Adventures was designed from the start as a solo experience, we also knew that people would enjoy playing it with others. We’ve been playtesting and working behind the scenes to bring some two player variants to the table that not only open up a seat for an additional player but also open up new ways to approach the game.
Two-Headed Giant
This cooperative mode really leans into the idea of co-op play. The two players must work in tandem using the same character, deck, and token tracker. But here’s the kicker: you split your starting items and McGuffins between the two of you. Additionally, you alternate taking turns, which means your items and McGuffins are only available half the time. Anytime you gain an item or McGuffin, you both gain one!
A lot of the fun in this variant comes from working together to find the best words and setting each other up for big turns. Don’t just take our word for it though; check out this gameplay video where we show off the mode over a couple different enemy fights.
Double Trouble
In the Double Trouble mode, each player has their own character to play! They team up against a pair of enemies, but they must coordinate their attacks and share certain resources—like the wild card!  (To make this possible, one enemy uses the tray from the unused character.)
 Paperback Playthrough with Aaron of GameEnthus and designer Skye Larsen
Playthrough from a Live Stream with Ruel Gaviola on Tabletop Tonight
Book 2 Gameplay from a Live Stream with Richmond of BramBeard Gaming
Jason Perez with One Stop Co-op Shop
You won't get too far in a roguelike without sweet loot. Reward cards for each enemy will give you two options to choose from. You have to choose which set of loot is more important to keep progressing.
Items provide powerful effects that can be used once per turn, but you'll need mana to activate most of them.  
Examples of a McGuffin and item with completed art
McGuffins are always double-sided, and you'll get to choose which McGuffin will help you more. These powerups provide modest effects, but don't require mana for use. Find the right ones for some spectacular combos!
Every character letter card is also upgradeable. When a reward says you upgrade a card, flip the card over and put it back in its sleeve. Some card upgrades add extra icons to the card, while others improve or even alter the card ability.

 Shipping will be charged in our post-campaign pledge manager after the campaign.  We ship customs friendly.
 Tim Fowers, co-designer, has piloted many successful games including Burgle Bros, Fugitive, and Paperback 
 Skye Larsen, co-designer, has finally justified his Creative Writing degree (sort of)
 Jeff Krause, development, worked with Tim on Sabotage and Burgle Bros 2 
 Ryan Goldsberry, illustrator, helps bring all of Tim's games to life
 Noah Adelman, product design, has designed components and storage solutions for many successful games through his company Game Trayz™
 We'd also like to thank Andrew Colin Beck for our logo design, Nate Stebbing for the animation work in our Kickstarter video, and Fernando Cunha for our gameplay animations on this page.
We will use a pledge manager to help our backers get their copy of Paperback Adventures as quickly as possible. Shipping costs will be added later through the pledge management system.
This campaign won't have any Kickstarter-exclusive components, but your pledge still means a lot! Here's how pledging now benefits both you and the game.
You will receive the game at a discount compared to after the campaign
Because the game will not go through distributors, it may not show up in your local store.
You can help guide our game's development. We will listen to our backers' thoughts and implement ideas and feedback where we can.
Finally, you'll be a big reason why we get the game to print and share it with others.

campaign.story:
Everyone knows dragons love hoarding gold in their caves and laying waste to any would-be intruders. But in an exclusive interview, one dragon finally revealed what they do when they’re not in the spotlight.

“Yeah I mean, of course we enjoy all the gold and the riches, but what we really love is winning.”
Apparently dragons have designed their own game using leftovers from those pesky intruders.
“Monsters, humans, you name it. If you come a-strollin’, heads will be rollin’, as we like to say. That’s actually how we came up with the name.”
When asked why they shared this long kept secret, 
 “We’ve enjoyed this game for centuries. It’s time the rest of the world got a chance to play.” 
Heads Will Roll is a pocket dexterity game designed by dragons that uses solid metal skulls rolled out each round, flicking at a goal, and passing through gates for bonus points along the way. It feels great in your hand, plays quick, and can be played almost anywhere.  If you've already got one of the earlier limited edition test runs of the game, don't fret! We're offering new sculpts, new rules, deluxe pieces, and a sweet oversized playmat with the art stylings of Nick Nazzaro!
Updated Skulls & Treasure Chest (Design Not Finalized)
No Stretch Goals
No Kickstarter Exclusives
No FOMO
What does COMPLETE AT LAUNCH mean? We are offering you the best game from the start. All gameplay elements and anything else that would have been a stretch goal is simply included in the game from day one. Kickstarter Exclusives do not exist on this campaign.
But what if we think of something awesome mid campaign? Or backers make a sweet suggestion? Then we will just give it to you if possible. No stretch goals to reach it. You'll just get an update that says you are getting a cool thing.
But what about sweet Kickstarter Exclusives? We want everyone to enjoy the products we create, and it feels like a punishment for someone to miss out just because they weren't on Kickstarter at the right time. While we might have limited amounts of items, nothing will be available only on Kickstarter.
Lay Waste Games was built by backers and will always be here to serve our customers, regardless of when they found out about us. Pledges and purchases on Kickstarter are a representation of a person's faith in a product and team, and for that, we want to give you the best product always.
 What's Eric Playing? 
 A Pawn's Perspective 
 The Rat Hole Review 
We love supporting everyone's FLGS, and this campaign is no different. Heads Will Roll base game cartons will be available to retailers in our pledge manager BackerKit. Email us at Hello@LayWasteGames.com for more information. 
We will be charging shipping after the campaign ends through BackerKit. This ensures you get charged the shipping you deserve based on your total order. No more, no less. 
 By doing this, we are able to factor in your pledge tier, add-ons, and all fancy things that may occur during the campaign. However, we can offer estimated shipping costs. Below is estimated pricing for one copy of the game AKA the $15 or $20 pledge tiers.
US: $6
INTERNATIONAL: $10
More Estimated Shipping Prices 
Please keep in mind these are estimates and there will be variations from country to country. Also, the more items you purchase, the more shipping will cost. If you have any questions, please email us at hello@laywastegames.com or message us on Kickstarter.
(If you live in Australia, Canada, the EU, or the United States, you will not pay any fees beyond shipping. Any shipments to countries outside of those countries will be subject to standard customs charges that are applicable.) 
For our UK Backers : We are currently working to find a solution that keeps shipping costs low for our UK backers. We are keeping an eye on how things develop with the new legislation in the UK regarding VAT collection for OMP sales, but cannot guarantee any solutions at this point in time. 
Please be aware, we cannot label games as gifts. Due to complications with shipping in the past, we will not be able to ship to Brazil and Russia. Apologies. 

Image by @electricmeat
Based strictly on this photo, we are a bad 90s prog rock band. But in reality, Lay Waste Games is a board game company owned and operated by Jake Given, Zach Given, Alyssa Marshall & Nick Nazzaro. The company was founded in 2014 with the sole goal of making Dragoon a reality. Over the past 6 years, we have successfully funded and delivered 5 Kickstarter projects, with the 6th (Dragoon : Might and Magma) shipping soon.
We will always make sure our games have the highest production value, incredible artwork, and solid gameplay. Without backers, Lay Waste Games would not exist, and our dedication to them will last forever.

LWG + KJ

Hey everyone! 
Hope you’re enjoying your April Fool’s Day! So we’ve got good news and even better news.  Slight manufacturing mix up— we got the quote from a grain manufacturer, not a game manufacturer, but it’s for the best! Rather than chunky metal pieces (gross no thanks!) now all the pieces are made out of bread! But we need backers to help us choose a new direction for the game. We’re torn between Heads Won't Roll, an inaction dexterity game using bread rolls where you score points based on the fascinating inanimate properties of bread, or , a gluten origami game where the bread infuriatingly always crumbles, and points are deducted.

First off- wow! What an incredible ride so far thanks to all of you!
So what DO the deluxe pieces add? When using the Gold Skulls, they are worth 3 points if you cross their line (6 if they’re in the same orientation), compared to the Silver Skulls (2/4) and the Monster Skulls (1/2). 
Additionally, you may turn the Monster Skulls into Poison Skulls, making them worth -2 points if you cross their line (-4 if in the same orientation), to add some real nice challenge and variety to your games. If you’re playing with the Variant Shield, you can roll it out with the rest of the pieces, and you get —but no bonus flicks are awarded for passing across skull lines.

Thank you everyone for a strong first few days of the campaign!
We had a request from one of our backers (hey William!) for some videos of the Heads Will Roll game pieces being used on a playmat. We're getting that content together for backers to check out, and will have it ready soon. Till then, here's a little teaser video!

Thank you so much to all our awesome backers, we've already raised twice our initial goal! 
Have you had a chance to check out Heads Will Roll on tabletop simulator? It's super cool.
Also, our artist Nick Nazzaro is leading a free workshop tonight about his artwork both in and out of the gaming industry! Register now!

Sunlight glaring through the windshield. Your favorite songs blasting through the speakers. Candy bar wrappers piled next to a warm drink in the cheap plastic cupholder. Your companion riding in the passenger seat, snapping pictures of landmarks as you settle into the hypnotic rhythm of the road. But be careful: this fun road trip could get dangerous as you drive through Death Valley.

Death Valley is a pocket-sized, push-your-luck, tableau building game for 1-2 players, with each traveler striving to assemble the best mix of cards in their Journey and Scrapbook in order to win the game.
Death Valley is 18 cards, packaged in a portable and durable wallet.

Each turn, players will choose whether to assign a card to their Journey, or move cards from their Journey to their Scrapbook. Cards feature stars (points), special abilities (affect the value and position of cards), and some interesting facts about Death Valley.

Each card also has a hazard (Heat, Terrain, Flood or Animals) listed. Having 3 of the same Hazard visible in their tableau will cause the player to bust and lose all the progress in their Journey.
All 4 hazards and their card distribution within the game.
At the end of the game the player with the most stars in their Journey, plus any additional points from card abilities, is the winner.
To set up the game, shuffle all 18 cards and place 1 face-up between the players. On a player’s turn they have 3 choices: add the face-up or face-down card from the top of the deck to their own Journey, or Rest. When a player Rests, they move at least one card from their Journey to their Scrapbook (stacking them into a single pile if they select multiple cards) and shuffle as many of their remaining Journey cards into the deck as they choose.
After the player takes their action for the turn, they check for Hazards among the visible cards in their Journey and Scrapbook. If they have 3 of the same Hazard type showing (3 Flood cards, for example) the player busts: 1 of the Hazard cards is removed from the game and the rest of the player’s Journey cards get shuffled back into the deck.
Once there is only one card remaining in the center area, the game ends. Each player counts up the stars showing in their Journey row. Visible cards in the Journey and Scrapbook might have abilities that adjust that score. Once all effects have been applied, the player with the highest star count is the winner.
Backseat Driver Variant
If you want to really press your luck and give up a little control, try out the Backseat Driver Variant. In this variant players may choose to play the face-up card on their opponent’s journey as well as their own. At the end of each turn you will check to see if either player busts.
Solo Mode - Designed by Kevin Ellenburg and Mike Mullins
The game will come with rules for solo play. Here you will face an AI explorer that thinks through its action each turn similarly to a player (playing the more intense Backseat Driver Variant). This explorer never rests in its pursuit of adventure.
If you would like to try the game yourself, the mostly black and white preview PNP is available at PNP Arcade now!
https://www.pnparcade.com/products/death-valley-kickstarter-preview
In previous campaigns we created expansion material and used it as stretch goals. Since 2018, we've just given it away from the start. So no worries on whether we'll hit it or not, you are getting bonus content if you pledge here. The free expansion for this campaign is Death Valley: Panamint City.
This expansion consists of 6 more cards, letting you customize the deck before playing Death Valley. Before play, organize all the base game and expansion cards by hazard type. Then select 3 Animal, 4 Flood, 5 Terrain, and 6 Heat cards to shuffle into the deck. Unselected cards will not be used. Includes Vultures, Panamint City, Red Cathedral, Ubehebe Crater, Zabriskie Point, and Panamint Dunes.
Here are the rewards available during this campaign.

To add more games to your order, you can do one of a few things:
US Backers only - to order games that ship now - go to our website http://www.buttonshygames.com and place an order using the coupon code "0321us" to get 15% off  of your order. Your website order will ship now, as long as you don't  order any pre-order items, otherwise the entire order will ship as  soon as everything comes in. As always, if you reach $25.00, you will  also receive free shipping. (NOTE: We previously offered a US Backer  code to combine games to save on shipping, but in most cases this was a  much better deal of free shipping AND 15% off.)
International Backers only - go to our website http://www.buttonshygames.com and place an order using the coupon code "0321international" (REPEAT: THIS IS FOR BACKERS ONLY) to get free shipping on your extra game(s). Note: The limit on this  offer is 3 wallet games (and up to 3 expansions) total, including  anything that you order at Kickstarter. Anything above 3 wallet games  (and 3  expansions)  will end up bumping into the next shipping tier,  which can be as much as  $10 on international orders. These games will  all ship together with your Kickstarter rewards.
There are many notable games and we'll be featuring those throughout the campaign.
While the game includes lots of great little historical facts about Death Valley, here's a little history about the game itself.
Death Valley was originally Kevin Ellenburg's entry to the 18 Card Challenge: Design A Game About A Real Life Location, and we’re happy to see it coming to life. It has a unique take on the familiar push-your-luck mechanic where players have to think about managing their hazards as well as the card abilities, making each choice matter beyond the immediate threat of busting. On top of that, the gorgeous art from Fachri Maulana perfectly captures the lonely beauty of Death Valley National Park.
First up is Kevin's initial pitch video in it's entirety (note some changes were made to the gameplay and cards throughout development):
And here is the 18 Card Challenge video where it was a finalist, along with two other games that we eventually published, Skulls of Sedlec and Horreos. All 3 of which are available here. 


We have an awesome following of repeat customers. As a result, we've built the Board Game of the Month Club.
It's a subscription service where you receive unreleased microgames,   promo cards, expansion content, and Kickstarter discounts ... every   month! Supporters also receive from $1 to $10 off EVERY WALLET GAME  that  we make. (Members back our Kickstarter projects at the $1 pledge  level  above.)
Our 2021 $5+ packages include an episode of The Final Lightyear.
Gather your crew and gear and launch into a  fringe section of space where the law teeters over the edge and a good  captain can earn a living. There's no shortage of threats that endanger  the goodfolk of deep space, but luckily your torpedo bay is full and  lasers are hot.
In Lightyear you'll play solo or cooperative with a friend, as the  captain of a so-called starship, in hopes of earning some rewards and a  decent rep. Using tactical maneuvering and dice-based action selection,  you'll work through the sector's small, medium and large enemies trying  to gain rewards and ultimately live to see another day. Customizable  episodes will challenge you with variable enemies and threats while  offering powerful new gear and talented crew to help you in your  adventures.
Our $10 packages include all of the above and something   extra. Generally it's a tiny game (up to 9 cards), or some expansion  / promo cards for our existing games.
And our $20 package includes all of the above and a copy of   the featured wallet game (or the wallet game of your choice).   The featured wallet games also come with any expansion material that  is given away in the Kickstarter campaigns (like the Panamint City expansion  here).
If that sounds cool to you, check out the Board Game of the Month Club on Patreon!
http://www.patreon.com/buttonshy
Thank you for checking out Death Valley!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With our method of publishing and using multiple manufacturers, there's always a chance that one part of the game could come in with an error, leading to delays. We've been able to minimize these errors in recent years, but they can happen from time to time. We've also upped our pre-press staff internally to make sure we can hit intended deadlines.

With COVID-19 some of our suppliers have been delayed, so we've been allowing additional time in our estimations and setting up backup suppliers as well. Our local staff is working while socially distancing, so we are allowing additional time for a smaller staff to assemble and ship games. 

Our unfulfilled projects are moving along according to schedule. Ugly Gryphon Inn is shipping now, two months ahead of schedule. Our Agropolis Campaign is scheduled to be fulfilled in March and backers are up to date with the progress. Our Reprint Campaign is due to fulfill in June and moving ahead as planned.

Available in multiple languages (Spanish, French, Chinese, AND GERMAN)! See the Licensing section for details!
Engage the Nazi occupation of France in la petite guerre to throw off the yoke of the oppressors and free your homeland!
Maquis is a solitaire worker-placement game with variable goals and a play time of approximately twenty minutes. The player places their resistance agents on spaces around town to achieve their goals - blowing up trains, publishing underground newspapers - but at the same time Milice collaborators and Wehrmacht soldiers patrol the area. Agents who can't make it back to the safe house at the end of the day are arrested, and never seen again.
With this new edition, we've added some new components to include some more difficult 3-star missions, some new spare rooms and resources, and made some tweaks to the rules & original components to improve clarity and gameplay.
For previous backers/customers who got the 1st edition, we have the option on this campaign to order the new components to add to your original game (Backer Level "Maquis - New Content"). They'll be fully compatible and will fit into the original box (with some maneuvering 😊), or you can keep them in the nice tuck box they'll ship in.
NOTE:  We only plan on printing what we need of the "Maquis - New Content" level so there is no guarantee that folks who don't back the Kickstarter will receive the new content separately. Don't miss out!



To begin, the player will set up the board, organize the game tokens and  randomly choose two mission cards that must be completed in the allotted number of turns.

The player will then shuffle the patrol deck and place it next to the side of the board. This deck represents where the Milice patrols will occur during each day.

The player will choose a location to send their first worker and assign one of their pawns there. They then draw a patrol card, and place a Milice pawn if able. This continues until all of the available worker pawns and Milice pawns are placed. If the Milice find your worker during patrol, they will be arrested!
Your diligent workers are then free to perform their duties, working toward your two goals. Gather resources, recruit fellow patriots to the cause, and undermine the enemy plans to throw off the yoke of oppression and free your homeland!

updates.update_userinfo: The inside track on the turn track
updates.update_content: Hi - game designer here. Let's be clear to the people worrying that a "fix" isn't happening to the 2nd printing board because of complaints: there was no "fix" in the first place, really. And to the people worrying that SRG are caving in to complaints - well, kind of, but the complaints came from me. This isn't just a reactionary response to a few people moaning in the comments, this is the game designer stepping in and saying that this isn't really as good change to make as it first seemed. What follows is a probably-overly-long explanation from me, just in case anyone wants to be reassured as to what this change is (and isn't), how this came about, and how it's mostly my fault anyway. ;-)

Hey everyone! We wanted to follow up yesterday's update and the subsequent comments. Due to an internal miscommunication and as a result of extended discussion, we've decided to keep the Day track for 2nd edition the same as it was in the 1st edition. The main goal of this is to maintain consistency between editions.
While there is some confusion on the Day track, we're confident that we can clarify the intended mechanics in the updated rules. This achieves 2 goals:
 1) Everyone will be on the same page when it comes to rules questions.
 2) If/when we release content in the future, there won't be any backwards compatibility issues.

updates.update_userinfo: Changes to 2nd Edition & Foreign Version Shipping Info
updates.update_content:
Hey everyone! Coming into the last few days of the campaign and we've blown past our previous records for number of backers & funds raised! We can't thank everyone enough for the amazing support. It'll be interesting to see where we end up at!
We wanted to let everyone know that we will be making a minor change that will effect the board, and a few cards. We feel the second edition is the perfect opportunity to make these adjustments that we overlooked during the lead up to the first Kickstarter. After a lot of deliberation between Jake (the designer) and the rest of the SRG team, we've decided to adjust the day tracker on the main board. As the game morphed from Jake's original print & play (PnP) design to the first edition, the day tracker became a little confusing. In the PnP and first editions, the day track marks "completed days". This wasn't an issue for any of the original PnP missions, but some of the newer ones require you to complete objectives on or before certain days. This leads to some counter-intuitive situations where, for example, your marker is on day 6 for that turn but you're actually in the middle of day 7.

Hey everyone! Again, just wow!!! We slammed through our previous best on number of backers and I think we'll cruise past our previous best in funding level. Can't thank everyone enough for all of the support - we truly appreciate it!
Wanted to get an update out there to show off some of the new content that will be in the 2nd edition (and content upgrade packs for 1st edition owners). First up, the new tokens that will be in the game:

Bandada (ban·da·da: Spanish)- noun: A number of birds traveling together.
ABOUT
Travel the world as you photograph beautiful birds. Get the best pictures by attracting birds with their favorite types of food. 
Will you have the best portfolio by the end?
In Bandada, 1 or 2 players will be selecting cards that have an action and a scoring method listed on them. The actions on the cards allow the players to manipulate the 12 food dice while the scoring section uses those dice to score points.
Once each player has 4 birds, the player with the most points is the winner!
HOW TO PLAY
Read the full rulebook here - READ THE FULL RULEBOOK
Try out the game on Tabletop Simulator.
Download the original print and play version HERE.

The base game includes a solo AI that you can play against for a quick, strategic game. You will also get the Solo Adventure Mode in which you'll travel across the world searching for specific birds. DUNGEONS - MAYHEM - MAGYK! These three words best describe SKÜLLBOX. Take on the role of sentient, punk skulls who need to use psychotic traps and weird contraband to keep wanna-be heroes from taking their stuff.
SKÜLLBOX is a punk rock-inspired 62-page zine that contains an entire rules-lite game designed to bring fun and absurd stories to your table. It has a unique engine at its core that can be learned in just a couple of minutes, requires only six-sided dice, and is designed to be played as a fun one-shot or a short yet absurd campaign.
For those afraid of a Kickstarter who’ll never deliver, fear no more! SKÜLLBOX is already written, all the art is done, and the layout is well underway. Once this campaign ends, it’ll only be a matter of ironing out some bugs, getting the zines printed, and shipping them out!
SKÜLLBOX uses a custom-made system with only three abilities: COOL, MOSH, and WEIRD. A skull rolls a number of d6 equal to their ability, succeeding if at least one die is a 5 or higher. Each skull also has its own BOX — a unique, strange apparatus that gives the skull weird powers to use to bash or ensorcell raiders. There are six total, from the fire-starting Tinderbox to the rockstar Bonebox Musician!
A session of SKÜLLBOX includes three or more raids. These are organized by the legendary musician-turned-tyrant, Saint-Queen Sophronia. Under her employ are screamo berserkers, warlocks who sold their soul to the ESTABLISHMENT, cubed slimes who don’t know any better, and things so terrifyingly powerful that the skulls will need more than just magyk boxes to bring them down.
That’s where the traps come in. SKÜLLBOX features 8 psychotic and weird traps that skulls can build to keep raiders out. Each trap comes with its own story prompt — a short explanation of a scene that has to be roleplayed out in order for the trap to be used. In SKÜLLBOX you’ll be figuring out the recipe needed to summon C’thulu’s own knife-wielding tentacles while persuading starved cannibals to take their revenge on the heroes that exiled them. And if you roll bonus successes when setting a trap up, you can spend them on bizarre modifications for your delectable torture devices.
No skull should go into battle with only a couple of advantages. Here are some more chaotic toys that you’ll be deploying in the fight against good:
Fields of magyk coffee-shrooms; a perfect boost for when things get dangerous!
  Weaponized contraband that can be found only on the black market.
  The legendary GOLDEN APPLE OF DISCORD, which doubles as a lifeline and your secret weapon!
 This 40-page zine has the following specifications, for your viewing pleasure:
45+ unique pieces of art, all by the visionary Gospo
  Perfect binding to lay flat our gorgeous spread pages
  6 unique boxes for skulls to play as
  8 psychotic traps for skulls to build
  11 unique raiders, from the shroom-awakened psionic Lurk to the majestic and regal Irish Elk
  4 pieces of magical contraband for the skulls to use
  Lore fit for insane cartoons
 Every single piece of art in SKÜLLBOX is drawn by the same visionary: GOSPO. The whacky-yet-punk skulls were designed for his son, as were the raiders facing off against them. His black and white illustrations shaped not only the foundation of SKÜLLBOX, but defined its flavor, atmosphere, and game mechanics too.
We also created a Spotify Playlist so that you can get the vibe of the SKÜLLBOX world.
  Either use the link above or open the app on your smartphone, click search and scan this:

updates.update_content:
Yo Skulls!
We got some great news for you today! Turns out the mass production of SKÜLLBOX is DONE! That’s right, all 500 copies of this bad skull, complete with UV lamination on the cover, new and better paper, darker blacks, the holographic sticker, and the envelope are all done.
Check out these sweet pics + the video that shows off what we got:

Hey, skulls!
MASSIVE update today! Guess who finally has their proofs?!

And we’ve funded!
Skulls, as of today, the Kickstarter has come to an end and we’ve managed to bring our headbanging project SKÜLLBOX into the world. With your help, we’ve dug the foundations for dungeons throughout Everbliss and planted the seeds for our Golden Apples of Discord; in other words, we’re ready to shake this place up and make our names heard!
But really though, thank you all so much for making this a reality. SKÜLLBOX is a love letter that started with Gospo making drawings for his son for their D&D games and has evolved into a punk rock, black and white, grunge story of rebellious survival and absurdist magyk.

By the Big Box, skulls, we’ve done it!
As of now, we are have surpassed our second and last stretch goal, $10,000 — which means a holograph sticker and an enamel pin will accompany every single zine! This has us absolutely thrilled, and we are deeply thankful for everyone that has believed in us so far.
We’re in the twilight of our campaign now. In less than 24 hours, SKÜLLBOX will be funded and the production process gets to the point where we can get this zine into your lovely, hero-crushing hands.

Yo skulls!
So, as we said at the start of this Kickstarter, the only thing left to finish was the layout. I'm proud to let you all know that the first draft of the layout is done, and it came with a heck of a surprise. What was once a humble 40-page zine has mutated into an insane, mohawk sporting 62 pages! To be honest, we just couldn't help ourselves — after all, Everbliss has got to get wrecked somehow, right?

campaign.story:
Queercore: How to Punk a Revolution: An Oral History is the very first comprehensive overview of the movement that defied both the music underground and the LGBT mainstream community–queercore. It began as a documentary film. Now it's a book with expanded material and in-depth interviews, never-before-seen photographs, reprinted zines, tons of images, and more. 
Help us get this assimilation-destroying book into the world. Learn more, preorder your copy today, and check out all the rewards below. Thanks for supporting this important new work!
 About the book
Through exclusive interviews with protagonists like Bruce LaBruce, G.B. Jones, Jayne County, Kathleen Hanna of Bikini Kill and Le Tigre, film director and author John Waters, Lynn Breedlove of Tribe 8, Jon Ginoli of Pansy Division, and many more, alongside a treasure trove of never-before-seen photographs and reprinted zines from the time, Queercore traces the history of a scene originally “fabricated” in the bedrooms and coffee shops of Toronto and San Francisco by a few young, queer punks to  its emergence as a relevant and real revolution. Queercore gets a down-to-details firsthand account of the movement explored through the people that lived it—from punk's early queer elements, to the moments Toronto kids decided they needed to create a scene that didn’t exist, to the infiltration of the mainstream by Pansy Division, and the emergence of riot grrrl as a sister movement—as well as the clothes, zines, art, film, and music that made this movement an exciting in-your-face middle finger to complacent gay and straight society. Queercore will stand as both a testament to radically gay politics and culture and an important reference for those who wish to better understand this explosive movement.
The book is edited by Liam Warfield, Walter Crasshole, and Yony Leyser with an Introduction by Anna Joy Springer and Lynn Breedlove.
*The project video is a trailer for the Queercore: How To Punk A Revolution film, which was written and directed by Yony Leyser, released in 2017, and 83 minutes. You can get the new book plus a DVD or Streaming of the documentary as a Reward!
Rewards
*Reward Update: 
Click to learn more about the film by Yony Leyser
Already a backer and want to upgrade your pledge? Learn how on your computer here and the App here.
Praise
“Finally, a book that centers on the wild, innovative, and fearless contributions queers made to punk rock, creating a punker-than-punk subculture beneath the subculture, Queercore. Gossipy and  inspiring, a historical document and a call to arms during a time when the entire planet could use a dose of queer, creative rage.” —Michelle Tea, author of Valencia
“I knew at an early age I didn’t want to be part of a church, I wanted to be part of a circus. It’s documents such as this book that  give hope for our future. Anarchists, the queer community, the roots of punk, the Situationists, and all the other influential artistic guts eventually had to intersect. Queercore is completely logical, relevant, and badass.” —Justin Pearson, Three One G Records
“This is a sensational set of oral histories of queer punk that includes everyone from Jayne County to Eileen Myles, from Vaginal Davis  to Lynn Breedlove. The whole book works like a giant jigsaw puzzle that never offers a final or complete picture but at least scatters the  pieces around to allow the reader to assemble some truly exciting scenarios. This is very possibly the best and only way that subcultural histories should emerge—namely as incomplete and incoherent, as a magnificent poly vocal roar, as sound, fury, rebel yells and screams. This does not just capture queer punk, it is queer punk.” —Jack Halberstam, author of The Queer Art of Failure and In A Queer Time and Place: Transgender Bodies, Subcultural Lives
“Queercore: How To Punk a Revolution delivers a deeply invested history of the forgotten roots of queercore. While to some, punk was inherently gay as fuck—the actual queer revolution came few and  far between bands, scenes, and eras whose intersections were small, yet wildly significant. With voices ranging from Penny Arcade to Brontez Purnell, we hear a vast history from around the globe; echoing everything queer, dirty, and true.” —Cristy C. Road, frontwoman of Choked Up and author of Spit and Passion and Next World Tarot
“Queercore is the unrelenting polyrhythm of a culture, chanted in varied waves of sensation, by some of its most essential voices. Zigzagging through generations of nostalgia and controversy faster than their own power chords, this is not just a record of queercore (the movement), but a theoretical discussion about the  intersectional ideology of ‘Queer,’ as well as ‘Punk’ itself. Reading—not watching or listening to—this book gave me the absolutely necessary opportunity to reinvigorate my own punk, both as performance art and radical protest. This unflinching oral history of how a subculture begins and survives, tenaciously layered in the present, is a bridge over the gap, that I for one, have been waiting for.” —JD Samson, musician, producer, songwriter and DJ (Le Tigre/MEN)

Sample writing from G.B. Jones
"We really started in the anarchist community. We didn’t really start in the gay community. We were trading with anarchist zines, and meeting anarchists from the States, and that was really our milieu—the punk scene, the post-punk scene, experimental filmmakers and artists. So we met all these people when we were touring and we’d show our films, and that’s how it started spreading. We’d take the zines with us when we traveled; we were kind of like this traveling circus, y’know—here’s the band!, and here’s the zine!, and here’s the movies! It was very much like the Exploding Plastic Inevitable. And I think that’s how it spread so quickly, because people were encountering it so many different levels."
Just a few images* from the book
*Images will be black and white
About the Contributors
Liam Warfield is a writer, editor, and educator living in Chicago.
Walter Crasshole is a journalist in Berlin and English-language editor for the city's 40-year running queer magazine Siegessäule. He is also a regular contributor and columnist for Exberliner, Berlin’s English-language magazine, covering queer and cultural topics. He occasionally translates books from German to English, having just finished his third book translation for punk performance artist Wolfgang Müller.
Yony Leyser grew up in Chicago and relocated to Berlin in 2010. He is the writer and director of three award-winning feature films William S. Burroughs: A Man Within; Desire Will Set You Free; and Queercore: How to Punk a Revolution. He has received critical acclaim in publications including the New York Times, the Guardian, Sight and Sound, and the Los Angeles Times.
Anna Joy Springer is the author of The Vicious Red Relic, Love (Jaded Ibis, 2011), an illustrated fabulist memoir with soundscape (Your Metaforest Guidebook), and The Birdwisher, A Murder Mystery for Very Old Young Adults (Birds  of Lace, 2009). Her work appears in zines, journals, anthologies, and  recordings. An Associate Professor of Literature at UC San Diego, she  teaches experimental writing, feminist literature and graphic texts.  She’s performed in punk and queercore bands Blatz, The Gr’ups, and  Cypher in the Snow and toured the U.S. with the writers of Sister Spit.  She lives in Los Angeles.
Lynn Breedlove is a writer, performer, musician,  entrepreneur and community activist born and raised in the SF Bay Area. He’s toured comedy solo shows and with bands Tribe8 and The Homobiles. He is the founder and CEO of Homobiles the ride service and author of Godspeed and Lynnee Breedlove’s One Freak Show.
About the book:
             Queercore: How to Punk a Revolution: An Oral History
             Editors: Liam Warfield, Walter Crasshole, and Yony Leyser • Introduction: Anna Joy Springer and Lynn Breedlove
             Publisher: PM Press
             ISBN: 9781629637969
             Format: Paperback
             Size: 6 x 9
             Page count: 224
             Subjects: Punk Music/Queer Studies
The project video is the trailer for the film, generously provided by Altered Innocence, a film distributor specializing in edgy and artistic foreign, queer, and coming-of-age cinema. Support their work!

https://buttonshygames.com/products/ugly-gryphon-inn

You own the questionably prestigious Ugly Gryphon Inn, which is the only Inn within a hundred miles. Your patrons are rowdy  and rude, but they are the only ones around. Your goal is to fill your inn with enough patrons to keep the debt collectors at bay, but to do so  you must manage some painfully particular, peculiar patrons.
In The Ugly Gryphon Inn, you’ll be tasked with managing your patrons’ various needs to ensure they all get a good night’s rest. Each turn, you’ll send one drowsy patron up to their room, then check to make sure all your patrons are sleeping soundly. If something’s irking them, they might raise a fuss, so keep an eye on what they need as you go. Afterwards, you’ll usher in more guests and keep an eye on the bar to make sure there’s no trouble. There’s never a moment to rest in The Ugly Gryphon Inn!
A quick note on our Simply Solo line
We kicked off our Simply Solo line in May of 2020 with Food Chain Island. Ugly Gryphon Inn is the second in the series. Each game is designed by Scott Almes and focuses on games that are one player only, light on rules and big on replayability. 
And now, a look at Ugly Gryphon Inn
The Ugly Gryphon Inn offers the kinds of brain-stretching puzzle that Scott Almes brought to our first Simply Solo title, Food Chain Island. While they’re both easy to dive into and endlessly replayable, here the focus is on managing each patron’s needs while preparing for the next round of requests. 
Carefully booking your guests in the right order is key to success, as each patron’s frustrations can have consequences for the sleepers below them. All the while, though, you’ll have to expect the unexpected to make sure each new guest is comfortable. With a horde of disgruntled customers on their way, you’ll have to be clever to run The Ugly Gryphon Inn.

Simply shuffle the deck of patron cards and place them in a face-down stack in front of you. Draw 4 cards and arrange them in a face-up row in front of you. These patrons are considered to be at the bar.
The game takes place in a series of turns until you’ve played all the cards from the deck and your hand. Each turn has the following flow:
Phase I: Patron goes to sleep
One of the patrons at the bar are ready for bed. Select a card from the bar area and place it at the top of the inn. The inn is a single vertical line of cards, with each card being a floor.
I choose to move the Sleepy Summoner into the Inn.
Check Rooms for Phase I irks. 
Starting with the Patron you just placed, you check each patron card from top to bottom. You check the statement on their card to see what will irk them and cause them to leave. If the conditions are met, then apply the effects on their card. 

Phase II: New Patron(s) Arrives
Adds one more patron to the bar until you have 4. If there are no cards left in the draw deck, then this is the final round.
I draw the Charitable Giant and add it to the Bar.
Check for Quirks
Evaluate the quirk icons in the bar. If there are 3 or more of the same type of quirk, then you irk all the Inn patrons that are sensitive to that bad effect! 
In the Bar there are 3 Fighting icons, which means anyone in the Inn that is irked by Fighting will trigger their effect.
Since the Sleepy Summoner is not irked by fighting, her effect does not trigger. She'll stay in the Inn!
Game End
After you’ve run out of cards in the deck, then count how many patrons you have in the inn. If you have 7 or more patrons in the inn - you’ve won! If you have less than 7 or if at any point 8 patrons are in the discard pile, then you have lost the game.

Try the game yourself! Download the preview PNP today at PNPArcade.com:
https://www.pnparcade.com/products/ugly-gryphon-inn-kickstarter-preview

And Purple Moose Plays did a full playthrough video. Check it out below:


In previous campaigns we created expansion material and used it as stretch goals. Since 2018, we've just given it away from the start.  So no worries on whether we'll hit it or not, you are getting bonus content if you pledge here. The free expansion for this campaign is Ugly Gryphon Inn: More Patrons.

You’ve finally cleared out the bar and sent everyone off to bed...but what’s that sound? A knock at the door, at this hour? Why, it’s just what you need: MORE patrons jostling for a spot at your inn! It’s gonna be a long night...
These expansion cards are shuffled into the starting deck, adding to the available Patrons found in the base game. You’ll need to manage these new needy customers more carefully, as your inn will require one more contented patron to be considered successful.
Here are the rewards available during this campaign. 


As you may have noticed, we have a second expansion available! Here's a little more info on Ugly Gryphon Inn: Local Dragons:

You’ve handled plenty of rowdy customers in your time, from monks and mages to giants and goblins, but there’s one thing you’ve never faced: the mighty Dragon. Now your humble inn has drawn the attention of an ancient wyrm. Pay close attention to who leaves and who stays: if your departing Patrons irritate the lurking Dragon, all your hard work is sure to go up in flames!


Each game using the Local Dragons expansion adds 1 of 3 possible Dragons to your Inn. As Patrons leave, check their symbols to see whether they provoke the Dragon. If the Dragon is sufficiently provoked -- two matching symbols accumulated -- you’ll lose the game.
You may have also noticed a new Food Chain Island expansion, Lost Beasts. This is the next in our line of expansions and is due to release in the next month or so here. It'll be initially available on our site for sale in small numbers, but if you are a Food Chain Island fan and want to combine it with your Kickstarter rewards to save a few dollars, we made a reward level here.  
We are waiting to see if Kickstarter approves any on-site add-ons for this campaign (it's still in a beta / invite only process), for the time being if you want to add more wallet games from our library (and we have a whole bunch!), we will do that in a different way.
To add more games to your order, you can do one of a few things:
US Backers only - to order games that ship now - go to our website http://www.buttonshygames.com and place an order using the coupon code "1220impatient" to get 15% off of your order. Your website order will ship now, as long as you don't order any pre-order items, otherwise the entire order will ship as soon as everything comes in. As always, if you reach $25.00, you will also receive free shipping. (NOTE: We previously offered a US Backer code to combine games to save on shipping, but in most cases this was a much better deal of free shipping AND 15% off.)
International Backers only - go to our website http://www.buttonshygames.com and place an order using the coupon code "1220international" (REPEAT: THIS IS FOR BACKERS ONLY) to get free shipping on your extra game(s). Note: The limit on this offer is 3 wallet games (and up to 3 expansions) total, including anything that you order at Kickstarter. Anything above 3 wallet games (and 3  expansions)  will end up bumping into the next shipping tier, which can be as much as  $10 on international orders. These games will all ship together with your Kickstarter rewards.
There are many notable games and we'll be featuring those throughout the campaign.
Scott Almes is best known for the Tiny Epic series by Gamelyn Games. He's gone even bigger with Heroes of Land, Air and Sea and with our Simply Solo line he's going even smaller. We first met in 2012 when Scott designed a game for our Storyteller Cards, and in 2020 we released Food Chain Island. Looking forward to more games in the Simply Solo line (and we might even tease the next one here in the updates).
We have an awesome following of repeat customers. As a result, we've built the Board Game of the Month Club.
It's a subscription service where you receive unreleased microgames,  promo cards, expansion content, and Kickstarter discounts ... every  month! Supporters also receive from $1 to $10 off EVERY WALLET GAME that  we make. (Members back our Kickstarter projects at the $1 pledge level  above.)

Our 2020 $5 packages include an episode of Personal Space, a solo game that has multiplayer interactions. It's part roll and write, part campaign, part digital, part real life, part fantasy. There are stickers and everyone receives some unique cards and unique combinations  of cards. It's been live for a few months now, and it's our most ambitious project yet and it will emerge until Feb 2021.

Then, we are starting up a new year long game in March. It's called Lightyear.
Gather your crew and gear and launch into a fringe section of space where the law teeters over the edge and a good captain can earn a living. There's no shortage of threats that endanger the goodfolk of deep space, but luckily your torpedo bay is full and lasers are hot.
In Lightyear you'll play solo or cooperative with a friend, as the captain of a so-called starship, in hopes of earning some rewards and a decent rep. Using tactical maneuvering and dice-based action selection, you'll work through the sector's small, medium and large enemies trying to gain rewards and ultimately live to see another day. Customizable episodes will challenge you with variable enemies and threats while offering powerful new gear and talented crew to help you in your adventures.

Our $10 packages include all of the above and something  extra. Generally it's a tiny game (up to 9 cards), or some expansion  / promo cards for our existing games.

And our $20 package includes all of the above and a copy of  the featured wallet game (or the wallet game of your choice).  The featured wallet games also come with any expansion material that is given away in the Kickstarter campaigns (like the Dragons expansion here).

If that sounds cool to you, check out the Board Game of the Month Club on Patreon!
http://www.patreon.com/buttonshy
Thank you for checking out Ugly Gryphon Inn!

campaign.story:
Welcome to The Mariana Trench, a solo or 2 player pocket sized game that plays in 10-15 minutes. Your objective as a deep-sea researcher is to guide your sub through fathoms of water, descending to the Trench floor, to find mysterious and amazing sea creatures.
Will you become a renowned research scientist, or will you fall victim to the creatures that lurk beneath the surface?
INTRODUCTION
The goal of The Mariana Trench is to score the most research points by researching deep-sea creatures and the floor of the trench. The game is played in alternating turns until your submarines run out of oxygen. 
MOVEMENT
Movement from one card to the next represents a distance of 1000 Fathoms. At launch your sub can move up to 2000 fathoms (2 cards) on your turn. 
COLLECTING RESEARCH AND UPGRADES
When researching the water column, reveal the (research) card next to your sub. Each card displays a deep-sea creature and a submarine upgrade. 
You may:
• Collect the deep-sea creature, or
• Upgrade your Submarine
If you do not collect the creature or upgrade your sub then leave the card face-up, where either player may collect it on a future turn.
If you have hold capacity you may tuck the research card under your sub (to the right), so that the class and size of the creature shows.
If you do not collect the sea creature then you can upgrade your sub. Tuck the card under your sub (to the left) so that the upgrade is showing. You cannot take the same upgrade twice.
Your sub starts with a small hold, which can carry one small creature. To collect large creatures you must upgrade your hold first.  

THE TRENCH FLOOR
Each time your sub reaches the trench floor you can conduct valuable scientific research. Take 1 research token from the supply and place it on your submarine. Your sub can only carry one research token at a time. The token is offloaded as soon as you surface beside the research vessel.  Research tokens are worth 2RP at the end of the game.
RETURNING TO THE RESEARCH SHIP
When your sub surfaces, all the creatures and tokens are offloaded to the research vessel. At the end of the game points are scored for different sets of creatures
And there is more….
OK, so we have the game, the expansion, and the play mat, we have a few awesome stretch goals to come too…. But what else?
Over the past three years I have been hugely fortunate to work in the board game industry, I’ve had games published, I’ve worked as an illustrator and designer on many fantastic and exciting games. 
But now is the time, the time for me to develop the games I’d like to play, the games I think you would like, games I'm passionate about which I'm itching to throw my creativity and time into. By backing this project, you are giving me the opportunity to exclusively make the absolute best games I can for you.
With two more amazing games in the pipeline for next year, I am massively excited for the future, I've got some amazing stuff to share. So, it’s not all about buying this game, it’s about investing in creative freedom and being part of an exciting journey and some amazing new games.
Tris Rossin.

campaign.story:
Welcome to the first publishing campaign from New Mill Industries!
The Science and Séance Society, designed by Daniel Newman, is an asymmetric card and dice game for two players that takes about 30 minutes to play.
You are members of The Science and Séance Society, a Victorian-era clandestine organization devoted to exploring the mysteries of reality. Each of you has chosen a unique method of dealing with a particularly nasty bit of chaos that has been summoned, and the friendly wager at hand will be won by the player whose approach proves most effective.  
The Science and Séance Society offers totally asymmetric gameplay in a tight, two player game. The below videos will give you an idea of how both sides differ in their approaches and show you how to play.
Each copy of The Science and Séance Society features the components listed and shown below:
18 Science Engine cards
3 Science Ability cards
4 Science Engine markers
8 red dice
8 black dice
8 white dice
Dice bag
Dice screen
Science reference card
22 Séance Tarot cards
5 Séance Ability cards
Séance reference card
Void card 
Read/watch these thoughts on the game, or better yet, try it for yourself on Tabletop Simulator. You can also read the final rules here.
What's Eric Playing Preview
Gameosity Kickstarter Preview
Blue Peg Pink Peg Interview
The Fandomentals Kickstarter Preview
We plan on creating and publishing games differently than most, so we feel like we should provide an explanation for why you should back during this campaign.
· The Science and Séance Society will not be in stores! We are only printing copies for the campaign and do not intend to sell it widely afterwards.
· The Science and Séance Society is thoroughly developed. It has been rules tested and played at events like Unpub and regular NYC playtest events.
· The Science and Séance Society is fun! If you like two player games, or asymmetric games, or just love clever card and dice games, The Science and Séance Society belongs on your shelf.
· The Science and Séance Society will not exist without this campaign. Your support means it, and future games from us, actually exist.
· The money earned is being spent responsibly to pay for manufacturing and Kickstarter fees. Any profit beyond that goes toward covering the cost of our labor as all other parties involved in the creation of this project have already been paid.
· Note: The number of pledges for this campaign are unlimited. However, since we are a small two-person studio doing fulfillment ourselves, we are capping each pledge level so that we can provide accurate and conservative delivery times. As one pledge level fills up, we will open a new one. These pledge levels are IDENTICAL other than which batch they will be shipped in. 
We at New Mill Industries will not be using Stretch Goals and our reasoning is simple.
We design each game holistically. Every game we offer you is feature complete and needs no additional content to feel that way. Our goal is to provide a product with great components, clean design, thoroughly tested mechanisms, and the best possible price. Stretch Goals are often antithetical to this goal. They can indicate a game that purposefully had content removed just to create Stretch Goals or it creates additional design and testing overhead that delays the final product from getting to you, the backer.While we would love to offer stretch goals that upgrade component quality for everyone, the scale at which we intend to print and the print-on-demand model makes these types of goals not feasible. 
New Mill Industries is a passion project for us, not our career. We are a two-person design studio and independent publisher who makes games because we love making games.

 In the United States, we will be sending the games in USPS Priority Mail Flat Rate Small Boxes. They fit like a glove. We're charging $8 for shipping up-front and hoping that USPS doesn't change its rates over the next month.  We're estimating shipping to be $20 for the 5-pack level. 
For Canadian and other international backers, we're setting the shipping cost to $20 and $25 respectively. We'll be using First Class mail rather than Priority Mail, so they may take a bit longer to get to you, but Priority gets extremely expensive for international shipments. We're planning on sending them as "gift" to avoid extra duties and import fees. As the rewards are technically not purchases from a store, we feel pretty good that we'd be in the clear here. We'll even gift-wrap them. The 5-pack level will also be available for all non-US countries at $30.

 We plan on printing only a few hundred games, which means we do not benefit from economies of scale, cannot partner with international distributors, and cannot assume the costs if things go wrong for international backers. We will also be hand-assembling your games so they will not be shrink-wrapped. While we would love to say that this is exclusively because it is more environmentally friendly, it also just isn't feasible for a company of our size.
New Mill Industries will be producing small print runs of games that feature clean design and quirky themes without all of the excesses of the modern board game publishing industry.
Daniel Newman is the designer of Dead Man's Cabal, Ahead in the Clouds, Feat On The Ground, and Rolled West. Daniel worked as an architectural model maker for a while but has been doing the stay-at-home dad thing for the last couple of years, as well as helping out with the NYC Playtest group. Daniel does the graphic design and pre-production work for New Mill Industries.
The self-proclaimed Purple People Meeter of the Warm Fuzzies Tribe, Tony Miller is the designer of Kabuto Sumo and one half of the design team of Fire in the Library. His job as an IT firefighter pays the bills so that he can design games and cohost the Breaking into Board Games podcast in between naps. Tony does the social media and fulfillment work for New Mill Industries.
The Science and Séance Society was rules edited by Travis D. Hill and this Kickstarter uses photography by Adeline Weyland.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are always risks to any Kickstarter. Here are our plans to reduce risk to ensure a smooth, great campaign.
1. The game design is finished. Aside from possible fine-tuning for printing, the game you're backing is the game you'll receive.
2. All art production is finished. We won’t have any deadlines extending due to production delays.
3. We’ve personally worked with each of our manufacturing partners and have a final copy of the game IN OUR HANDS. You can see it in the pictures above! We are sourcing every component from US vendors which allows for fast turnaround and easy resolution to customer service issues.
4. We promise that if anything is wrong with your game, we will fix it. If you have questions on how to play, we will answer them. Whether it's replacing missing components for free or answering emails for someone struggling with the rules, We will make it right.

Hello all of you wonderful backers! Just wanted to pop in here and give you an update on the latest goings-on with production since our last update.

First things first, we received the test printing of the cards incorporating changes that were made during the campaign and we are very happy with how they turned out!

Hello distinguished members of the Society! We wanted to send you an update on our progress. Since Kickstarter released the funds to us this week, we have begun ordering all of the components and assembling all of the shipping materials that we need.

In our last update we released the Print and Play and sent out surveys so that we could collect your addresses. So far we have received responses from all but 26 of you which is an incredible response rate! Feel free to pat yourselves on the back for doing such a great job!

As we bring our first ever Kickstarter to a close we could not be any happier! While we celebrate the successful launch of New Mill Industries (and Halloween) we are also gearing up to shift our operation into fulfillment mode.

campaign.story:
Leaves whispering, chickens clucking, tractors rumbling, the sounds of a bustling farm are everywhere. The countryside is blossoming and you are in charge of it all. The last team of planners couldn’t cut it, so the farmers turned to your team, the best of the best. If anyone can turn this little farm into a flourishing ranching community, it’s you!
Agropolis is a standalone Sprawlopolis game. What does that mean? Well it's more of what we built with Sprawlopolis, but instead of more cities, it's farms. It adds a few new twists (livestock and feed fees), and can be played on its own or combined with Sprawlopolis in a fun new way. 
Agropolis will be the 66th game to join our growing line of Wallet Games
A quick note on Sprawlopolis
We've made over 60 Wallet Games by now and it's safe to say that there's something really special about Sprawlopolis. It has been nominated for the Golden Geek Awards for Best Card Game and Best Solo Game, was voted #31 in the 1-Player Guild's People Choice Top 200 Solo Games, and has received the Dice Tower's Seal of Excellence.
It's been a wild ride.
It's gone on to have multiple sold out printings, and is currently available in many languages from our publishing partners from all over the world. Once again, a very special game and we are really excited to expand on it. 
And now, a look at Agropolis
In Agropolis, 1-4 players work together to build a new farm from the ground up. Using only 18 cards and a variable scoring system, the game is never the same twice. 
First, players will randomly flip over 3 cards to see the scoring rules for the game.

In this game, you will try to keep Pig Pens adjacent to your longest road, align your Orchards into specific polyomino shapes, and keep your Cornfields on the corners of the map.
But  not only do these 3 cards determine how you will score this game, they  also determine how you win. Total up the values of all three cards, and that number is the score that you need to reach in order to win.

The example above is just one of many, many combinations (816 to be  exact!). Each game has drastically different scoring rules in unique  combinations, and a new score to beat, ranging from 6 to 51 points.

A look at half of the scoring conditions in Agropolis
Each turn, players will play one card from their hand to the growing countryside, trying to score as many points as possible.
Players will have to communicate and plan without revealing their own cards in order to most efficiently develop large areas in each of the 4 zone types.
Watch out though, road maintenance isn't cheap and each road will cost you points in the end.
New to Agropolis are the three types of livestock pens, each in two different configurations.
And finally there's the Feed Fee: a fun (and optional) new way to raise the goal just a little bit, making for a tougher game.
When all cards have been placed, the game ends and players see if they have met the dynamically generated minimum score for their game.
Can you meet the demands of the farmers, work with your fellow planners and build the ultimate agricultural wonder? It’s time to find out!

Download the preview PNP today at PNPArcade.com!
https://www.pnparcade.com/collections/new-games/products/agropolis
We'll start with a little coverage of the original game, Sprawlopolis. It's been out for 2 years now and has slowly built up a stable of great reviews and video content. Here are a few of note:
And now for Agropolis.

Use this expansion to create the perfect mix of city and farm zones in a single game. It adds 6 cards with scoring conditions relying on both Sprawlopolis and Agropolis, along with a few really interesting new rules (you'll draw one card from each game, choose one to play, and then discard the other). campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With our method of publishing and using multiple manufacturers, there's always a chance that one part of the game could come in with an error, leading to delays. We've been able to minimize these errors in recent years, but they can happen from time to time. We've also upped our pre-press staff internally to make sure we can hit intended deadlines.

With COVID-19 some of our suppliers have been delayed, so we've been allowing additional time in our estimations and setting up backup suppliers as well. Our local staff is working while socially distancing, so we are allowing additional time for a smaller staff to assemble and ship games. 

Our two unfulfilled projects are moving along according to our updated schedule. Our Food Chain Island project is starting to ship this week. Our Game Haul Bag Campaign is still over a month away from fulfillment, but is on track as planned.

updates.update_content:
Hello everyone! 
We are down to the very very end here. As of right now, I can count 37 packages that Marty is working on shipping. These were ones that had address issues or other issues that needed to be resolved. After that we have another 15 that are in the process of resolving the issues. Aside from that, I need to do a final check on addresses that errored - sometimes they are too long, or have characters that the mail program doesn't recognize. I believe there may be 10 or so of those at a quick count. Which puts us at about 52 packages out of almost 6500. Less than 1% left. :)

updates.update_userinfo: Missed last week's update, but we're 88% shipped!
updates.update_content: Sorry for missing last week's update. It was quite a week here. We were getting the shipping team into place in the main office and realizing the difficulty of the assembly team being in the other office. This just meant I was driving games between offices all day, carrying them up and down stairs and questioning whether it would be faster just to assemble them myself (the answer is that it's not, but all of that back and forth can get to your head). Then after that physical and logistical nightmare, I had a technological nightmare to deal with.

Last week was week 3 of shipping. By now we expected to be at 37.5% shipped, but we hit 55% shipped, breaking that crucial halfway point. We currently have 3595 out the door as we're heading into week 4. This week we are shifting gears and working on some of the more complex and slower packages as we wait for a new batch of Sprawlopolis Interstate rules to arrive. Once those arrive on Friday, I'll cut them all, assign the team to start sleeving them and week 5 will be a huge wave of All-opolis again. 
There isn't much else to report at this time, but as we hit the middle, I am beat! So many trips from office to office, and back and forth to the post office. But we have some great news about both of those. First we were able to move our shipping team into the main office as they are both vaccinated (the assembly team is still in another building in the next town over). Second, because there is now someone working out of our main office all the time, we were able to FINALLY arrange for daily post office pick-ups. No more fighting for a parking space then paying to park, then hauling 9 bins just to stand in line at the post office.

updates.update_userinfo: Week two of shipping is done and we are at....
updates.update_content:
Hello everyone! 
Here's our week two shipping update. :) 
Last week we hit 2976 shipped, getting us to 45% of the campaign out the door!

updates.update_userinfo: 25% of the packages are out the door!
updates.update_content:
Hey everyone! We're been shipping for a week and hit 25% shipped. That's 1636 packages out the door. We are still expecting a 6-8 week fulfillment, as those were some of the easiest and fastest ones to move, but it feels great to hit that mark. We're really seeing what our assembly and shipping limits are here, and our crew of 5 people per day (plus me and my kids) are really working nicely. Next week we add a 6th person, just to make sure other things aren't falling behind while most of the group is focused on Agropolis.
I'll post one of these each Monday, letting you know where we are at.

updates.update_userinfo: March update: The cards are shipping out to us tomorrow!
updates.update_content:
This is the email I've been waiting for. It isn't much, but it's everything I wanted: 
This means the cards will arrive here next week. From there, our work is cut out for us. It's going to be about 300 hours of separating and assembly (I really should show off our silly process), so we are now bringing in a few more workers to try to get that down to about 4-6 weeks of assembling. Mail will happen along side of that, probably mailing 1200 a week for the same 4-6 weeks. Keep in mind, all of this won't start until they get here, which should be next week if all goes well.
